addressleaf.section:
My letter to my L. Treasuro
r
. Ma
r
18. 88

page.lettertext:
Belgia 1589 s
t
Rom 18 March to my L Treasurer
Ryght Honourable my veary good Lord, I writte in my laste of
the 9 of this moneth, of the
States
besieging of
Gertrudenberge,
a resolution secretly taken w
th
Counte Maurice
, not w
th
the p
r
vitie
of the
Counsell of State
, nor yeat of their owne assemblie, but
by th'advise of some certayne, of w
ch
in my former to yo
r
L. I
named the principall: whose proceedinges ar all so violente, and
so headdy, as far myne owne parte I can forsee no better consequ
e
t
then a daungerous alteration in the state of this gouvernment.
This theare are many of the cheifest hear that see, and confesse,
& yeat suffer to go forward, every man respecting his owne
quiettnes and ease. I have signified amonge them as occasion
hath bin offered, the dislike w
ch
I thinke her
Ma
tie
will conceave
of this forceable course, consideringe they have not, as beco
m
ed
them in dutie, accquaynted her w
th
it. They alleadge that
they have often heartofore complayned to her Ma
tie
, but still
received both from her, and from her ministers, fair promisses,
and no effectes: but wear rather by that meanes p
r
vented in
their purposes. Howbeit uppon th'examination of it w
th
them, it doth appeare that they have
not
dealte w
th
her Highnes
in such effectuall manner, & so often, as in such a cause, and in
goode correspondence it was requisite, before they had resolved
to use this extremitye. This the greater parte hear will acckno-
leadge, & rather wishe that any other meanes had bin practi-
sed, then this of open hostilitie. Notw
th
standinge if it had
come to the question of the meanes, consideringe the unrulie
disposition of those in Gertrudenberge, I can not tell what
to saye els, but
Non perinde dii aduarii posse, quid optim
u
factu sit, qu
a
pessim
u
fuisse, quod fact
u
est
. For the assemblinge of thease
forces agaynst the Towne, hath veary much weakened the garrisons
of
Zelande,
&
Overisell:
whearby it is thoughte that th'ennemy
er be longe
fol.117v
er be longe, wilbe drawen to some enterprise: especially then, when
S
r
John Norrice
is de
tie. The Counte hath fortified in divers plac
neer Gertrudenbergh, so as it is thought th'ennemy cannot come to it:
& hath besides cutte the dickes, & lett in the water rounde aboute,
Nevertheles they w
th
in seeme veary resolute, havinge as it is saide
artilery, powder, shotte, men, & victualls sufficiente. Once or
twice th'ennemy at
Bridow,
hath made fiers in the nighte, but
those of Gertruden
b
have not answeared agayne. The
sixe shippes w
ch
weare promised heare to S
r
John Norris, I
do not thincke wilbe sente. for those deputies of the States that
are heare, alleadge they can do nothinge w
th
out the reste, that are
absente at the siege: whearby the shippes ly fower at
Amsterdam,
and
two at
Enchusen
unprepared: w
ch
I do construe as done of
sette purpose, for that they are not dealte w
th
all by her Ma
tie
in
those Complaintes w
ch
they have made aboute the supernumeraries
in the Cautionarie townes, and in divers other pointes, as they
p
r
tend they ought to be by Contracte. Whearuppon, as occasions are
presented, I am
suaded they will shew some greater discontentmente.
I am forced by reason of
M
r
Secretaries
indisposition, to trouble
yow
r
L. more w
th
my l
re
s, then is fitte, or then I woulde, hopinge
that for the bette
r
cariage of mysealfe in this ticklishe state, yo
r
L. will vouchesafe me so much of yo
r
honourable favoure, as to
procure me some kinde of direction and answear to suche matters
of mo
m
ente as I have delivered in my former letters & writings
whearw
th
allwayes reco
m
endinge my humble searvice and dutie to
yo
r
L. I cease to trouble yow further.
From the Hage. Martii: 88. Yow
r
L. moste humbly bounden
